title: Israel-Iran live updates: Trump weighs U.S. strikes against Iran, but says he hasn’t decided
description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei made the comments as President Donald Trump weighs entering the conflict between Israel and Iran.
author: Andrew Jeong, Niha Masih, Abbie Cheeseman, Vivian Ho, Angie Orellana Hernandez, Joshua Yang, Sammy Westfall
byline: Andrew Jeong, Niha Masih, Abbie Cheeseman, Vivian Ho, Angie Orellana Hernandez, Joshua Yang, Sammy Westfall, Amaya Verde, Álvaro Valiño, N. Kirkpatrick, Matt Viser, Elahe Izadi, Claire Parker, Brianna Tucker, Susannah George, Karen DeYoung, Lior Soroka, Alon Rom, Abigail Hauslohner, Natalia Abbakumova, Patrick Svitek, Amy B Wang, Robyn Dixon, Alex Horton, Maham Javaid, Warren P. Strobel, Dan Lamothe, Yeganeh Torbati, Gerry Shih, Evan Hill, Christian Shepherd, Michael Birnbaum
excerpt: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei made the comments as President Donald Trump weighs entering the conflict between Israel and Iran.
text: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Wednesday in a post on X that his country does not fear President Donald Trump’s threats and “absurd rhetoric.” In a television address, he vowed that Iran “will not surrender” and said any U.S. military intervention in the conflict would bring “irreparable damage.” Trump is weighing whether to strike Iran, and the Pentagon has built up U.S. military forces in the Middle East in recent days. Trump told reporters Wednesday he had not come to a decision: “I may do it, I may not do it,” he said. Israel and Iran continued to trade fire on Wednesday, the sixth day of the direct conflict.What else to know on the sixth day of the Israel-Iran conflictReturn to menuExplosions were heard in Tehran early Wednesday as Israeli warplanes continued to hammer Iran. The Israeli military issued evacuation warnings for another district as the exodus from the Iranian capital continued. Israel said it attacked a centrifuge production site and several weapons manufacturing sites overnight. Iran launched two waves of missiles at Israel overnight and said it used its hypersonic Fattah-1 missile for the first time. There have been no reports of casualties in Israel on Wednesday.The number of missiles Israel has faced in each retaliation barrage appears to have decreased over the past two days. Iran has not explained the decline, but Israel said it has destroyed more than a third of Iran’s missile launchers.“The battle begins,” Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, posted on social media early Wednesday, hours after President Donald Trump described him as an “easy target.” As Trump mulls U.S. involvement, Esmaeil Baqaei, a spokesman for Iran’s Foreign Ministry, said in an interview with Al Jazeera that “any American intervention would be a recipe for an all-out war in the region.”Live coverage contributors 32Return to menuIsraeli warplanes are currently conducting strikes on Tehran “and additional areas in Iran,” the Israel Defense Forces said early Thursday.Mapping strikes in the Israel-Iran conflictReturn to menuAirstrikes continued for a sixth day Wednesday amid the most intense faceoff in the history of the Israel-Iran conflict.The confrontation that began Friday, when Israel launched an air campaign targeting Iran’s nuclear program and its military leaders, has since escalated, prompting President Donald Trump to consider possible U.S. involvement.This is an excerpt from a full story.Trump is as unpredictable as ever, even when faced with war Return to menuDoes he want to be a wartime president, or the broker of peace? Can he convince his MAGA base that going to war with Iran isn’t the kind of Middle Eastern entanglement he has spent more than a decade warning against? Is the moment for diplomacy over, or are the Iranians coming to the White House?He himself doesn’t seem to yet know.This is an excerpt from a full story.Iran FM: Iran acts only in self-defense, is committed to diplomacyReturn to menuIran’s foreign minister in a lengthy social media post Wednesday evening listed things that “the whole world should know,” including that Iran acts “solely” in self-defense and has “never sought” nuclear weapons. He also said Iran is committed to diplomacy with any country but Israel.‘Post Reports’ podcast: Will the U.S. bomb Iran? Return to menuPresident Donald Trump is weighing whether to strike Iran. On today’s episode of “Post Reports,” our Pentagon reporter Dan Lamothe and investigative reporter Carol Leonnig discuss how this decision could alter Trump’s political future — and the world.Podcast episodeArab leaders working to ‘get Iran to back down,’ former official saysReturn to menuEgypt, desperate for stability in the region, “is not happy” about the escalation between Israel and Iran, or the possibility of U.S. involvement, said a former Egyptian official close to the government who spoke on the condition of anonymity to share information about sensitive diplomacy beyond what appears in public statements.“We are in a very bad situation from the economic point of view,” the former official said.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump’s afternoon meeting in the Situation Room has ended, according to a White House official.Trump said earlier Wednesday that he would be meeting in the war room about the Israel-Iran conflict.Return to menuIf the conflict between Israel and Iran continues, “it is going to be bad for the region and it is going to be bad for everyone who has business in that region,” said Mirette Mabrouk, a senior fellow at the Middle East Institute focused on economic development and regional security.Politically, the region is “already on tenterhooks because of Gaza,” Mabrouk said. And economic strains caused by an escalation of conflict between Israel and Iran could threaten the stability of countries such as Egypt and Jordan, where “the economy is often central to political security and stability.”Iran warns gulf countries that U.S. bases there could be targets Return to menuIran has warned its Persian Gulf neighbors that U.S. bases in their territories will be legitimate targets in the event of a U.S. attack on Iran, the latest signal that Israel’s strikes risk igniting a wider regional war.Rights group says death toll in Iran far higher than official countReturn to menuA Washington-based rights group that monitors Iran said Wednesday that at least 585 people have been killed and 1,326 injured in Israeli attacks over the last five days. Iran’s Health Ministry said Sunday that 224 people had been killed and 1,277 injured, but the government has not yet provided an updated death toll.For many of the casualties, it remains unclear whether they were civilians or combatants.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump convened reporters to the Oval Office on Wednesday and was asked early on about possible U.S. action against Iran.“I have ideas as to what to do,” Trump said, adding that no final decision had been made regarding the Israel-Iran conflict. Trump also said a Situation Room meeting would take place later Wednesday.Return to menuUnited Nations Secretary General António Guterres called for an “immediate de-escalation leading to a ceasefire” between Israel and Iran in a statement Wednesday.“Any additional military interventions could have enormous consequences, not only for those involved but for the whole region and for international peace and security at large,” Guterres added.He condemned the “unnecessary loss of lives" and said diplomacy is the best method to address concerns related to Iran’s nuclear program.These Iran nuclear sites are in Israel’s crosshairs as U.S. weighs strikes Return to menuPreventing Iran from developing nuclear weapons has been the primary goal of U.S. and Israeli policy toward Iran for decades. The Iranian nuclear program has existed in some form since the 1950s, when Iran was ruled by a U.S.-backed monarchy and Washington supported the development of an Iranian civil nuclear sector. On Friday, Israel launched a wave of strikes on Iran, including on its nuclear facilities. As the United States weighs whether to join Israeli efforts to take out Iran’s nuclear program, here’s what we know about the sites that Israel has attacked so far, why they are so difficult to destroy and what nuclear hazards the strikes could pose.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuMore than 300 Pakistani families, students, and pilgrims arrived at the Taftan land border crossing from Iran on June 18, Pakistani officials said. (Video: AP)More than 300 Pakistani nationals arrived at the Taftan land border crossing between Iran and Pakistan on Wednesday, Pakistani officials said. Pakistan closed its border with Iran on Monday, according to provincial officials, but has allowed Pakistani citizens to evacuate from Iran.Return to menuThe first recovery flights — bringing back Israeli nationals stuck abroad as a result of the conflict — landed Wednesday in Israel from Athens, Rome, Milan, Paris and Larnaca, Cypress, El Al airlines said in a news release. The airline expects to operate eight more recovery flights Thursday.There are currently no outbound flights from Israel. However, according to the Israeli media, the government on Wednesday night will discuss resuming them Friday for diplomats, tourists and foreign nationals.Israel closed its airspace to commercial flights shortly after its initial strikes on Iran.Return to menuIn a statement Wednesday evening, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu once again profusely thanked President Donald Trump as a “great friend” to Israel and for his support in “defending Israel’s skies.”“We are in continuous communication, including last night,” he said. “We had a very warm conversation.”U.N. nuclear watchdog says it is still working on the ground in Iran Return to menuThe International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the United Nations’ atomic watchdog, still has inspectors on the ground in Iran, IAEA Director General Rafael Grossi told the agency’s board of governors Monday. “The Agency is and will remain present in Iran,” Grossi added. “Safeguards inspections in Iran will continue as soon as safety conditions allow.”The IAEA monitors satellite imagery, installs cameras within Iran’s nuclear facilities and regularly sends inspectors for in-person verification.Return to menuDefense Secretary Pete Hegseth suggested Wednesday that the Pentagon has made military preparations for a “day after” in Iran. “Have you commissioned any ‘day-after’ planning? Any force protection, any use of ground troops in Iran, any cost assessments?” Sen. Elissa Slotkin (D-Michigan) asked Hegseth during a hearing before the Senate Armed Services Committee. Slotkin, a former CIA analyst who served three tours in Iraq, noted that the U.S. failure to plan adequately for the “day after” in its invasion of Iraq and intervention in Afghanistan has left many Americans “deeply concerned” about what would follow from a new American war in the Middle East.“Have you authorized day-after planning?” she asked Hegseth.“We have plans for everything,” he replied, without offering any further detail.Return to menuRussia’s Foreign Ministry said Wednesday that “we are millimeters away from catastrophe” as Israel continues to fire missiles against Iran’s nuclear facilities, which spokeswoman Maria Zakharova described as “peaceful civilian infrastructure, under the control of [International Atomic Energy Agency] observers.”Return to menuIn a post published solely in Farsi, the Israel Defense Forces suggested that Iranians with knowledge of Iran’s “security apparatus” who “have expressed fear, despair, and anger over what is happening in Iran” contact the Mossad, Israel’s intelligence agency, using a VPN.“Perhaps there, you will find a new path to improve your situation,” the post said.Iran’s chief justice warned Monday that anyone arrested on suspicion of spying for Israel will be given swift trials and punishment, the semiofficial Tasnim News Agency reported.Israel targets Iran’s nuclear program, and stays mum about its ownReturn to menuAs Israel continues to target Iran’s nuclear facilities, its leaders have remained tight-lipped about its own clandestine nuclear program, built up in secret over seven decades into what experts believe to be the largest arsenal in the region.Return to menuDefense Secretary Pete Hegseth declined Wednesday to discuss the possibility of the United States bombing Iran, including whether President Donald Trump has asked him for options to do so.“If I had or I had not, I wouldn’t disclose that in this forum,” Hegseth said while testifying before the Senate Armed Services Committee.Hegseth was responding to questions from Sen. Jeanne Shaheen (D-New Hampshire), who said she hoped the public would be informed “as soon as consideration about action [in Iran] is determined.”Return to menuMinutes after saying he had not decided whether to strike Iran, President Donald Trump was asked whether he had given Iranians an ultimatum.“Uh,” Trump said, pausing and pursing his lips. “You could say so. They know. They know what’s happening. Maybe you could call it the ultimate — the ultimate ultimatum, right?”Asked what he meant by that, Trump replied, “Oh, I don’t want to say — look, I mean, give me a break.”Trump says he hasn’t decided on Iran strike: ‘I may do it, I may not do it’Return to menuPresident Donald Trump told reporters on June 18 he hasn’t decided whether to strike Iran’s nuclear facilities. (Video: The Washington Post)President Donald Trump said he hasn’t decided whether to strike Iran’s nuclear facilities, scoffing at a question Wednesday about where his mindset is.Bread and fuel lines, shock and fear, as civilians flee TehranReturn to menuTehran was eerily quiet as Alireza, 40, fled the city Tuesday afternoon. The Iranian capital “was under a deathly silence, broken intermittently by the sound of explosions,” he told The Washington Post in a phone interview around midnight, providing only a first name to preserve anonymity, fearing reprisal from authorities.Return to menuDefense Secretary Pete Hegseth and the United States’ top military commander, Dan Caine, are testifying on Capitol Hill on Wednesday morning, as President Donald Trump appears on the brink of ordering direct U.S. military involvement in Israel’s war with Iran.The men are likely to face searing questions from members of the Senate Armed Services Committee, who want to know how involved the U.S. military is already — and how far Trump is prepared to go.Putin puts himself forward as mediator again in call to UAEReturn to menuRussian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday continued his effort to put himself forward as a mediator in the Israel-Iran conflict, this time in a phone call with United Arab Emirates President Mohamed bin Zayed al-Nahyan, even as hopes for a swift end to the crisis waned.What is the Massive Ordnance Penetrator, the U.S. bunker-busting bomb? Return to menuIn the event the United States enters the escalating conflict between Israel and Iran, a likely focus will be on degrading or destroying Tehran’s underground facilities that enrich nuclear material.That task would most likely fall to a small number of Air Force strategic bombers that are capable of delivering 30,000-pound precision-guided bombs designed to destroy subterranean targets. This bomb, the GBU-57, is better known as a “bunker buster” or the Massive Ordnance Penetrator.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuRussian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov warned that the United States would probably intervene in the Middle East conflict since it had done so before. “We caution Washington against that kind of even speculative options. This would be a radically destabilizing step in the whole situation,” he said.Map: Where Israeli strikes have hit Iran since FridayReturn to menuThe map includes the locations of the TESA Karaj workshop and the Tehran Research Center, two centrifuge production facilities in Iran that the International Atomic Energy Agency said on Wednesday were hit.Return to menuThe Israel Defense Forces said Wednesday it has struck over 1,100 targets in Iran since its surprise offensive launched Friday. Israel targeted five AH-1 helicopters at Kermanshah Airport in western Iran, saying they had been set to strike Israeli aircraft, according to a statement from IDF spokesman Effie Defrin. Videos on Iranian Telegram accounts, which could not be immediately verified, showed large plumes of smoke and described “continuous explosions.”Iran ‘will not surrender to anyone’, supreme leader says Return to menuIn a televised speech on June 18, Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said that American involvement in Iran would backfire. (Video: WANA via Reuters)Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said Wednesday that Iran is not frightened by threats from President Donald Trump, as Israel and Iran continue to trade airstrikes.“The US President threatens us. With his absurd rhetoric, he demands that the Iranian people surrender to him. They should make threats against those who are afraid of being threatened. The Iranian nation isn’t frightened by such threats,” Khamenei said in a post on X.Post Reports podcast: A major turning point in the Israel-Iran conflictReturn to menuPodcast episodeIsrael and Iran have been exchanging attacks since Friday, leaving more than 20 people dead in Israel and more than 200 dead in Iran. On today’s episode of Post Reports, reporter Yeganeh Torbati speaks to host Elahe Izadi about why Israel chose this moment to launch strikes against Iran, whether Iran’s government could fall, and whether the U.S. and President Donald Trump will get involved.Return to menuForeign Minister Gideon Saar said Wednesday that Israel is “determined to continue” its fight against Iran, which he accused of deliberately targeting civilians. “There are no negotiations,” Saar told about 30 foreign ambassadors at the site of an Iranian missile attack in Bat Yam. “The operation will continue until we achieve our objectives.”Pentagon expands Middle East response as Israel, Iran trade strikesReturn to menuThe Pentagon is expanding its military presence in the Middle East and Europe in response to worsening hostilities between Israel and Iran, U.S. officials said Monday, sending refueling planes and an additional aircraft carrier among the resources dispatched. More than two dozen tanker planes were deployed from the United States to Europe on Sunday and Monday, a movement that U.S. officials linked to commanders’ desire for options should American facilities near the warring countries face a direct threat. The move puts those aircraft closer to the Middle East to defend U.S. interests if needed, said one official familiar with the discussion, who like some others spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the issue’s sensitivity.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuTwo centrifuge production facilities in Iran have been hit, the U.N. nuclear watchdog said Wednesday, identifying them as the TESA Karaj workshop and the Tehran Research Center. “At the Tehran site, one building was hit where advanced centrifuge rotors were manufactured and tested,” the International Atomic Energy Agency said on X. “At Karaj, two buildings were destroyed where different centrifuge components were manufactured.”Return to menuIran has launched over 400 missiles and hundreds more drones at Israel since the conflict broke out Friday, according to Wednesday morning data from the Israeli prime minister’s office. In that time, they have penetrated air defenses and hit more than 40 sites, the office said, adding that tax authorities have received more than 18,000 claims for damage, mostly to properties and buildings.Return to menuThe Israeli military confirmed for the first time Wednesday that Iran had successfully downed an Israeli drone with a surface-to-air missile. Iran’s state broadcaster IRIB had earlier broadcast footage of the wreckage of what appeared to be an Israeli Air Force Hermes 900 in the Isfahan province. Israel has denied previous Iranian reports of its aircraft being shot down in Iran.The young Iranian poet who lost her life in an Israeli strikeReturn to menuShe dreamed of seeing the band Coldplay live in concert. She loved trying new foods and was learning Italian. She wrote poetry constantly and shared it with friends and family. She was so proud of having summited Iran’s highest peak, Mount Damavand, that she made sure to mention that fact to everyone she met.She was, as her friends described in phone interviews and text messages this week, as bright and full of life as the sunflowers that she adored.This is an excerpt from a full story.Israel-Iran conflict could last only as long as their missiles hold outReturn to menuThe intensity of Iran’s barrages appears to be sharply dropping. After firing more than 150 missiles on the first night of the conflict, Friday, Iran fired a barrage of just 10 on Tuesday afternoon. Even so, Israeli analysts caution that more than half of Iran’s arsenal remains intact, and an unknown quantity of missiles may be hidden in underground depots.This is an excerpt from a full story.China’s Xi expresses concern over conflict between Israel and Iran Return to menuChinese leader Xi Jinping has said he was “deeply concerned” about a spike in tensions in the Middle East after Israel’s attacks on Iran, in his first comments on the conflict.“We oppose any act that infringes on the sovereignty, security and territorial integrity of other countries,” Xi told Uzbekistan’s president, Shavkat Mirziyoyev, in a meeting Tuesday.Return to menuThe U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem will remain closed through Friday, it said in a statement late Tuesday, as the conflict between Israel and Iran continued to flare.“We have no announcement about assisting private U.S. citizens to depart at this time,” the statement said.Return to menuVideo posted on social media June 18 shows huge plumes of smoke in the Tehran area after the IDF announced strikes on Iranian weapons manufacturing sites. (Video: Reuters)Israeli warplanes struck a centrifuge production site and missile production facilities in Iran, the Israel Defense Forces said early Wednesday. The airstrikes aimed to degrade Iran’s ability to build nuclear weapons, it said. According to the IDF, the centrifuge site helps Iran expand uranium enrichment for nuclear weapons development, and Iran manufactures components for surface-to-surface and surface-to-air missiles at the production facilities.Trump debates bombing Iran in pivotal moment for presidencyReturn to menuPresident Donald Trump faced one of the most monumental decisions of his presidency on Tuesday as he debated whether to join a war against Iran that risked sucking Washington into a new Middle Eastern conflict but also offered the chance to eliminate a foe’s nuclear program.On social media, the president said warned Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khameini that he was an “easy target,” and demanded “UNCONDITIONAL SURRENDER” without defining what that would mean.This is an excerpt from a full story.
html:
Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Wednesday in a post on X that his country does not fear President Donald Trump’s threats and “absurd rhetoric.” In a television address, he vowed that Iran “will not surrender” and said any U.S. military intervention in the conflict would bring “irreparable damage.” Trump is weighing whether to strike Iran, and the Pentagon has built up U.S. military forces in the Middle East in recent days. Trump told reporters Wednesday he had not come to a decision: “I may do it, I may not do it,” he said. Israel and Iran continued to trade fire on Wednesday, the sixth day of the direct conflict.

What else to know on the sixth day of the Israel-Iran conflict

Return to menu

  • Explosions were heard in Tehran early Wednesday as Israeli warplanes continued to hammer Iran. The Israeli military issued evacuation warnings for another district as the exodus from the Iranian capital continued. Israel said it attacked a centrifuge production site and several weapons manufacturing sites overnight. Iran launched two waves of missiles at Israel overnight and said it used its hypersonic Fattah-1 missile for the first time. There have been no reports of casualties in Israel on Wednesday.
  • The number of missiles Israel has faced in each retaliation barrage appears to have decreased over the past two days. Iran has not explained the decline, but Israel said it has destroyed more than a third of Iran’s missile launchers.
  • “The battle begins,” Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, posted on social media early Wednesday, hours after President Donald Trump described him as an “easy target.” As Trump mulls U.S. involvement, Esmaeil Baqaei, a spokesman for Iran’s Foreign Ministry, said in an interview with Al Jazeera that “any American intervention would be a recipe for an all-out war in the region.”

Live coverage contributors 32

  • Return to menu

    Israeli warplanes are currently conducting strikes on Tehran “and additional areas in Iran,” the Israel Defense Forces said early Thursday.

  • Mapping strikes in the Israel-Iran conflict

    Return to menu

    Airstrikes continued for a sixth day Wednesday amid the most intense faceoff in the history of the Israel-Iran conflict.

    The confrontation that began Friday, when Israel launched an air campaign targeting Iran’s nuclear program and its military leaders, has since escalated, prompting President Donald Trump to consider possible U.S. involvement.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Trump is as unpredictable as ever, even when faced with war

    Return to menu

    Does he want to be a wartime president, or the broker of peace? Can he convince his MAGA base that going to war with Iran isn’t the kind of Middle Eastern entanglement he has spent more than a decade warning against? Is the moment for diplomacy over, or are the Iranians coming to the White House?

    He himself doesn’t seem to yet know.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Iran FM: Iran acts only in self-defense, is committed to diplomacy

    Return to menu

    Iran’s foreign minister in a lengthy social media post Wednesday evening listed things that “the whole world should know,” including that Iran acts “solely” in self-defense and has “never sought” nuclear weapons. He also said Iran is committed to diplomacy with any country but Israel.

  • ‘Post Reports’ podcast: Will the U.S. bomb Iran?

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump is weighing whether to strike Iran. On today’s episode of “Post Reports,” our Pentagon reporter Dan Lamothe and investigative reporter Carol Leonnig discuss how this decision could alter Trump’s political future — and the world.

    Podcast episode

  • Arab leaders working to ‘get Iran to back down,’ former official says

    Return to menu

    Egypt, desperate for stability in the region, “is not happy” about the escalation between Israel and Iran, or the possibility of U.S. involvement, said a former Egyptian official close to the government who spoke on the condition of anonymity to share information about sensitive diplomacy beyond what appears in public statements.

    “We are in a very bad situation from the economic point of view,” the former official said.

  • Return to menu

    President Donald Trump’s afternoon meeting in the Situation Room has ended, according to a White House official.

    Trump said earlier Wednesday that he would be meeting in the war room about the Israel-Iran conflict.

  • Return to menu

    If the conflict between Israel and Iran continues, “it is going to be bad for the region and it is going to be bad for everyone who has business in that region,” said Mirette Mabrouk, a senior fellow at the Middle East Institute focused on economic development and regional security.

    Politically, the region is “already on tenterhooks because of Gaza,” Mabrouk said. And economic strains caused by an escalation of conflict between Israel and Iran could threaten the stability of countries such as Egypt and Jordan, where “the economy is often central to political security and stability.”

  • Iran warns gulf countries that U.S. bases there could be targets

    Return to menu

    Iran has warned its Persian Gulf neighbors that U.S. bases in their territories will be legitimate targets in the event of a U.S. attack on Iran, the latest signal that Israel’s strikes risk igniting a wider regional war.

  • Rights group says death toll in Iran far higher than official count

    Return to menu

    A Washington-based rights group that monitors Iran said Wednesday that at least 585 people have been killed and 1,326 injured in Israeli attacks over the last five days. Iran’s Health Ministry said Sunday that 224 people had been killed and 1,277 injured, but the government has not yet provided an updated death toll.

    For many of the casualties, it remains unclear whether they were civilians or combatants.

  • Return to menu

    President Donald Trump convened reporters to the Oval Office on Wednesday and was asked early on about possible U.S. action against Iran.

    “I have ideas as to what to do,” Trump said, adding that no final decision had been made regarding the Israel-Iran conflict. Trump also said a Situation Room meeting would take place later Wednesday.

  • Return to menu

    United Nations Secretary General António Guterres called for an “immediate de-escalation leading to a ceasefire” between Israel and Iran in a statement Wednesday.

    “Any additional military interventions could have enormous consequences, not only for those involved but for the whole region and for international peace and security at large,” Guterres added.

    He condemned the “unnecessary loss of lives" and said diplomacy is the best method to address concerns related to Iran’s nuclear program.

  • These Iran nuclear sites are in Israel’s crosshairs as U.S. weighs strikes

    Return to menu

    Preventing Iran from developing nuclear weapons has been the primary goal of U.S. and Israeli policy toward Iran for decades. The Iranian nuclear program has existed in some form since the 1950s, when Iran was ruled by a U.S.-backed monarchy and Washington supported the development of an Iranian civil nuclear sector. On Friday, Israel launched a wave of strikes on Iran, including on its nuclear facilities. As the United States weighs whether to join Israeli efforts to take out Iran’s nuclear program, here’s what we know about the sites that Israel has attacked so far, why they are so difficult to destroy and what nuclear hazards the strikes could pose.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    More than 300 Pakistani nationals arrived at the Taftan land border crossing between Iran and Pakistan on Wednesday, Pakistani officials said. Pakistan closed its border with Iran on Monday, according to provincial officials, but has allowed Pakistani citizens to evacuate from Iran.

  • Return to menu

    The first recovery flights — bringing back Israeli nationals stuck abroad as a result of the conflict — landed Wednesday in Israel from Athens, Rome, Milan, Paris and Larnaca, Cypress, El Al airlines said in a news release. The airline expects to operate eight more recovery flights Thursday.

    There are currently no outbound flights from Israel. However, according to the Israeli media, the government on Wednesday night will discuss resuming them Friday for diplomats, tourists and foreign nationals.

    Israel closed its airspace to commercial flights shortly after its initial strikes on Iran.

  • Return to menu

    In a statement Wednesday evening, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu once again profusely thanked President Donald Trump as a “great friend” to Israel and for his support in “defending Israel’s skies.”

    “We are in continuous communication, including last night,” he said. “We had a very warm conversation.”

  • U.N. nuclear watchdog says it is still working on the ground in Iran

    Return to menu

    The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the United Nations’ atomic watchdog, still has inspectors on the ground in Iran, IAEA Director General Rafael Grossi told the agency’s board of governors Monday. “The Agency is and will remain present in Iran,” Grossi added. “Safeguards inspections in Iran will continue as soon as safety conditions allow.”

    The IAEA monitors satellite imagery, installs cameras within Iran’s nuclear facilities and regularly sends inspectors for in-person verification.

  • Return to menu

    Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth suggested Wednesday that the Pentagon has made military preparations for a “day after” in Iran. “Have you commissioned any ‘day-after’ planning? Any force protection, any use of ground troops in Iran, any cost assessments?” Sen. Elissa Slotkin (D-Michigan) asked Hegseth during a hearing before the Senate Armed Services Committee. Slotkin, a former CIA analyst who served three tours in Iraq, noted that the U.S. failure to plan adequately for the “day after” in its invasion of Iraq and intervention in Afghanistan has left many Americans “deeply concerned” about what would follow from a new American war in the Middle East.

    “Have you authorized day-after planning?” she asked Hegseth.

    “We have plans for everything,” he replied, without offering any further detail.

  • Return to menu

    Russia’s Foreign Ministry said Wednesday that “we are millimeters away from catastrophe” as Israel continues to fire missiles against Iran’s nuclear facilities, which spokeswoman Maria Zakharova described as “peaceful civilian infrastructure, under the control of [International Atomic Energy Agency] observers.”

  • Return to menu

    In a post published solely in Farsi, the Israel Defense Forces suggested that Iranians with knowledge of Iran’s “security apparatus” who “have expressed fear, despair, and anger over what is happening in Iran” contact the Mossad, Israel’s intelligence agency, using a VPN.

    “Perhaps there, you will find a new path to improve your situation,” the post said.

    Iran’s chief justice warned Monday that anyone arrested on suspicion of spying for Israel will be given swift trials and punishment, the semiofficial Tasnim News Agency reported.

  • Israel targets Iran’s nuclear program, and stays mum about its own

    Return to menu

    As Israel continues to target Iran’s nuclear facilities, its leaders have remained tight-lipped about its own clandestine nuclear program, built up in secret over seven decades into what experts believe to be the largest arsenal in the region.

  • Return to menu

    Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth declined Wednesday to discuss the possibility of the United States bombing Iran, including whether President Donald Trump has asked him for options to do so.

    “If I had or I had not, I wouldn’t disclose that in this forum,” Hegseth said while testifying before the Senate Armed Services Committee.

    Hegseth was responding to questions from Sen. Jeanne Shaheen (D-New Hampshire), who said she hoped the public would be informed “as soon as consideration about action [in Iran] is determined.”

  • Return to menu

    Minutes after saying he had not decided whether to strike Iran, President Donald Trump was asked whether he had given Iranians an ultimatum.

    “Uh,” Trump said, pausing and pursing his lips. “You could say so. They know. They know what’s happening. Maybe you could call it the ultimate — the ultimate ultimatum, right?”

    Asked what he meant by that, Trump replied, “Oh, I don’t want to say — look, I mean, give me a break.”

  • Trump says he hasn’t decided on Iran strike: ‘I may do it, I may not do it’

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump said he hasn’t decided whether to strike Iran’s nuclear facilities, scoffing at a question Wednesday about where his mindset is.

  • Bread and fuel lines, shock and fear, as civilians flee Tehran

    Return to menu

    Tehran was eerily quiet as Alireza, 40, fled the city Tuesday afternoon. The Iranian capital “was under a deathly silence, broken intermittently by the sound of explosions,” he told The Washington Post in a phone interview around midnight, providing only a first name to preserve anonymity, fearing reprisal from authorities.

  • Return to menu

    Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and the United States’ top military commander, Dan Caine, are testifying on Capitol Hill on Wednesday morning, as President Donald Trump appears on the brink of ordering direct U.S. military involvement in Israel’s war with Iran.

    The men are likely to face searing questions from members of the Senate Armed Services Committee, who want to know how involved the U.S. military is already — and how far Trump is prepared to go.

  • Putin puts himself forward as mediator again in call to UAE

    Return to menu

    Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday continued his effort to put himself forward as a mediator in the Israel-Iran conflict, this time in a phone call with United Arab Emirates President Mohamed bin Zayed al-Nahyan, even as hopes for a swift end to the crisis waned.

  • What is the Massive Ordnance Penetrator, the U.S. bunker-busting bomb?

    Return to menu

    In the event the United States enters the escalating conflict between Israel and Iran, a likely focus will be on degrading or destroying Tehran’s underground facilities that enrich nuclear material.

    That task would most likely fall to a small number of Air Force strategic bombers that are capable of delivering 30,000-pound precision-guided bombs designed to destroy subterranean targets. This bomb, the GBU-57, is better known as a “bunker buster” or the Massive Ordnance Penetrator.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

    Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov warned that the United States would probably intervene in the Middle East conflict since it had done so before. “We caution Washington against that kind of even speculative options. This would be a radically destabilizing step in the whole situation,” he said.

  • Map: Where Israeli strikes have hit Iran since Friday

    Return to menu

    The map includes the locations of the TESA Karaj workshop and the Tehran Research Center, two centrifuge production facilities in Iran that the International Atomic Energy Agency said on Wednesday were hit.

  • Return to menu

    The Israel Defense Forces said Wednesday it has struck over 1,100 targets in Iran since its surprise offensive launched Friday. Israel targeted five AH-1 helicopters at Kermanshah Airport in western Iran, saying they had been set to strike Israeli aircraft, according to a statement from IDF spokesman Effie Defrin. Videos on Iranian Telegram accounts, which could not be immediately verified, showed large plumes of smoke and described “continuous explosions.”

  • Iran ‘will not surrender to anyone’, supreme leader says

    Return to menu

    Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said Wednesday that Iran is not frightened by threats from President Donald Trump, as Israel and Iran continue to trade airstrikes.

    “The US President threatens us. With his absurd rhetoric, he demands that the Iranian people surrender to him. They should make threats against those who are afraid of being threatened. The Iranian nation isn’t frightened by such threats,” Khamenei said in a post on X.

  • Post Reports podcast: A major turning point in the Israel-Iran conflict

    Return to menu

    Podcast episode

    Israel and Iran have been exchanging attacks since Friday, leaving more than 20 people dead in Israel and more than 200 dead in Iran. On today’s episode of Post Reports, reporter Yeganeh Torbati speaks to host Elahe Izadi about why Israel chose this moment to launch strikes against Iran, whether Iran’s government could fall, and whether the U.S. and President Donald Trump will get involved.

  • Return to menu

    Foreign Minister Gideon Saar said Wednesday that Israel is “determined to continue” its fight against Iran, which he accused of deliberately targeting civilians. “There are no negotiations,” Saar told about 30 foreign ambassadors at the site of an Iranian missile attack in Bat Yam. “The operation will continue until we achieve our objectives.”

  • Pentagon expands Middle East response as Israel, Iran trade strikes

    Return to menu

    The Pentagon is expanding its military presence in the Middle East and Europe in response to worsening hostilities between Israel and Iran, U.S. officials said Monday, sending refueling planes and an additional aircraft carrier among the resources dispatched. More than two dozen tanker planes were deployed from the United States to Europe on Sunday and Monday, a movement that U.S. officials linked to commanders’ desire for options should American facilities near the warring countries face a direct threat. The move puts those aircraft closer to the Middle East to defend U.S. interests if needed, said one official familiar with the discussion, who like some others spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the issue’s sensitivity.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    Two centrifuge production facilities in Iran have been hit, the U.N. nuclear watchdog said Wednesday, identifying them as the TESA Karaj workshop and the Tehran Research Center. “At the Tehran site, one building was hit where advanced centrifuge rotors were manufactured and tested,” the International Atomic Energy Agency said on X. “At Karaj, two buildings were destroyed where different centrifuge components were manufactured.”

  • Return to menu

    Iran has launched over 400 missiles and hundreds more drones at Israel since the conflict broke out Friday, according to Wednesday morning data from the Israeli prime minister’s office. In that time, they have penetrated air defenses and hit more than 40 sites, the office said, adding that tax authorities have received more than 18,000 claims for damage, mostly to properties and buildings.

  • Return to menu

    The Israeli military confirmed for the first time Wednesday that Iran had successfully downed an Israeli drone with a surface-to-air missile. Iran’s state broadcaster IRIB had earlier broadcast footage of the wreckage of what appeared to be an Israeli Air Force Hermes 900 in the Isfahan province. Israel has denied previous Iranian reports of its aircraft being shot down in Iran.

  • The young Iranian poet who lost her life in an Israeli strike

    Return to menu

    She dreamed of seeing the band Coldplay live in concert. She loved trying new foods and was learning Italian. She wrote poetry constantly and shared it with friends and family. She was so proud of having summited Iran’s highest peak, Mount Damavand, that she made sure to mention that fact to everyone she met.

    She was, as her friends described in phone interviews and text messages this week, as bright and full of life as the sunflowers that she adored.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Israel-Iran conflict could last only as long as their missiles hold out

    Return to menu

    The intensity of Iran’s barrages appears to be sharply dropping. After firing more than 150 missiles on the first night of the conflict, Friday, Iran fired a barrage of just 10 on Tuesday afternoon. Even so, Israeli analysts caution that more than half of Iran’s arsenal remains intact, and an unknown quantity of missiles may be hidden in underground depots.

  • China’s Xi expresses concern over conflict between Israel and Iran

    Return to menu

    Chinese leader Xi Jinping has said he was “deeply concerned” about a spike in tensions in the Middle East after Israel’s attacks on Iran, in his first comments on the conflict.

    “We oppose any act that infringes on the sovereignty, security and territorial integrity of other countries,” Xi told Uzbekistan’s president, Shavkat Mirziyoyev, in a meeting Tuesday.

  • Return to menu

    The U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem will remain closed through Friday, it said in a statement late Tuesday, as the conflict between Israel and Iran continued to flare.

    “We have no announcement about assisting private U.S. citizens to depart at this time,” the statement said.

  • Return to menu

    Israeli warplanes struck a centrifuge production site and missile production facilities in Iran, the Israel Defense Forces said early Wednesday. The airstrikes aimed to degrade Iran’s ability to build nuclear weapons, it said. According to the IDF, the centrifuge site helps Iran expand uranium enrichment for nuclear weapons development, and Iran manufactures components for surface-to-surface and surface-to-air missiles at the production facilities.

  • Trump debates bombing Iran in pivotal moment for presidency

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump faced one of the most monumental decisions of his presidency on Tuesday as he debated whether to join a war against Iran that risked sucking Washington into a new Middle Eastern conflict but also offered the chance to eliminate a foe’s nuclear program.

    On social media, the president said warned Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khameini that he was an “easy target,” and demanded “UNCONDITIONAL SURRENDER” without defining what that would mean.
